utterances: I mean, it's so frustrating to see that those whom we work day and night to assist are again bleeding to death because of this senseless war where men with arms seem to be willing to fight to the last child and woman.
At the same time, it's very fulfilling to see that we can save lives.
And we can hold people alive until there is a peaceful settlement.
Jan Egeland is secretary general of the Norwegian Refugee Council.
He's also an adviser to the U.N.'s special envoy on Syria.
Thank you so much.
Thank you.
It's the topic many dread at the Thanksgiving table, politics.

NPR's Scott Detrow went in search of an answer.
The Syrian refugee crisis feels like just the latest high-profile news event where Republicans and Democrats seem to be living in parallel universes.

All of this really bothers Ray LaHood, a longtime Republican congressman from Illinois who also served in President Obama's cabinet.
LaHood recently wrote a book called, ""Seeking Bipartisanship."" He told public television station WTVP that Obama didn't do enough to reach across the aisle.
They could've said, hey, we're going after some Republicans.
We're going to invite some Republicans down here for dinner and see what do you need for us to get this bill passed?
What does it take?
I find people's bafflement about the failures of bipartisanship baffling.
That's Dartmouth political scientist Brendan Nyhan.
He argues that competition between two political parties with two very different agendas is how American democracy works.
Nyhan has a name for the wine-and-dine outreach approach that LaHood and so many others suggest as a fix for partisanship.
He calls it the green lantern theory of the presidency.
Which is the idea that if the president only tried hard enough, he could get whatever it is he wants.
It's based on the powers of a comic book hero.
UNIDENTIFIED MAN #2: In brightest day.

This sounds a lot to me like what happened with the Justice Society, back in the ‘50s, with all the McCarthy, the House Un-American Affairs Committee, and you know, this reveal your identity or, you know, hang up your cape, kind of thing.

Well, Joe Quesada, that's something, yeah, and after this, can we accept the idea that in these titanic struggles between creatures with enormous powers, there might be a little collateral damage from time to time?
Well, I guarantee you this: there's going to be a lot of collateral damage.
The outcome of this series, we basically picked, as we're thinking about, you know, we're not really taking a side in this, but a side dos have to win.
Because if you're promising an event of this sort of magnitude, you can't just have a draw at the end of it.

So there will be some tremendous, tremendous changes to the Marvel universe after this.
And you can start finding out about them tomorrow in your local comic book store.

The American poet Emily Dickinson is the subject of a new film called ""A Quiet Passion."" The writer and director is Terence Davies.
He's best known for his depictions of working-class life in his native Britain.
The American actress Cynthia Nixon plays the poet.
NPR's Lynn Neary says the film creates an image of a complicated woman whose poetry is steeped in pain.
Terence Davies discovered Emily Dickinson on television.
An actress was reading one of her poems.
And afterwards, Davies ran out and bought one of the collections.
Davies became fascinated by this brilliant poet whose work was never recognized while she was alive and who rarely left her family home in Amherst, Mass.
I think she was afraid of life.
Like a lot of geniuses, you knew that she had skin missing, and that makes you very, very vulnerable.
Dickinson's life story was compelling, Davies says, but it was the poetry that drew him to her.
What moves me about all her poems I've read is everything is distilled down to the bare essential, but it's the very reticence of that that makes it desperately, desperately moving.
In the film, Davies uses Dickinson's poetry as a kind of commentary on her life.
In the opening scene, Dickinson is severely chastised by the headmistress of her school because she refuses to say she wants to be a Christian.
Dickinson is dismissed as a no hoper.
As the scene ends, she stands alone by a window as Cynthia Nixon reads one of her poems.
(SOUNDBITE OF FILM, ""A QUIET PASSION"")
